reply.author: Parth Sharma
reply.text:
Houthi Rebels (A group) based in Yemen attacked the oil and petroleum processing facilities of Saudi Arabia by drones.
So now,Saudi Arabia can not export the amount of petroleum it used to earlier. 
There will be a shortage of supply of oil in international market and whenever there is shortage of supply and demand is higher (by countries who import like India) ,price increases.
In short,India mein petrol ke daam 5rs/litre tak badhne waale hein.

Counter points-
1) No need of huge losses to its own assets, Saudi Arabia being chair of OPEC could have simply passed a unanimous resolution to increase prices as in past.
2) Saudi Arabia might itself want to get involved,but it cannot hope USA to get involved in real terms. Removal of hardliner Mr. Bolton shows slight spirit of reconciliation. Moreoevr USA has even expressed to hold talks with Mr. Khameini at G7 Biaritz summit.
3)Saudis may not want a war themselves,as it places whole west asian region in a potentional of turmoil,considering Iran has strike capability in almost all of its neighbours and beyond.
4) Saudis will not be foolish to underestimate Iranians as they have their experience in Yemen,where they thought of winning within 1 year, but now its been 4 years and Houthis are still not relenting.

author: cyril philip
text: The government is way behind investment in new and renewable energy with the targeted installed capacity for solar power lagging behind.

reply.author: c.v.vineet Bhat
reply.text: Do u think we can be self sufficient by solar? We don't have so much land , only thing we can do is nuclear energy based on thorium

reply.author: cyril philip
reply.text:
Read my comment carefully. “New and renewable energy”- It includes a bunch of energy sources. My comment in no way implies that solar energy will make us self sufficient(Don’t put your words in my mouth). I have said nothing against nuclear power. But now I am tempted to. 

Nuclear energy exploits resources (mining and extraction of minerals)and results in wastes which need complex management. Plus it needs foreign investment and imported raw materials. Why did India try for membership in NSG?How do u think the Kudankulam nuclear reactor was established? Have u heard about Indo-US nuclear deal? Also, today’s nuclear technology will result in environmental catastrophes. Have u heard of Fukushima? All this is because the current nuclear reactors are based on fission technology-splitting the atom to release energy and for this we need atoms of enriched minerals. Remember Kudankulam is near sea and a possibility of tsunami cannot be ruled out. This is why the world has moved from fission to fusion tech in nuclear energy. Checkout the miniature sun project in which India also is an investor.  

All I mean to say is we need clean , efficient and affordable energy for ensuring our energy security. Plus don’t worry about the lack of space for solar panels. Have u seen rooftop solar installations?

reply.author: c.v.vineet Bhat
reply.text: @cyril philip why don't u go to Google and search India's 3 stage nuclear program. By the way all Indians cannot afford solar rooftops , no production of monocrystal solar panels happens in India(on large scale).we need to import  it from China.and India is low income country ppl can't afford and think if govt gave subsidy then also no big battery's are available. Battery tech is very much neglected in India. These ideas are for high income countries.

reply.author: cyril philip
reply.text:
Now we’re talking.  At least this time u made fewer assumptions about my thoughts. I believe that renewables and nuclear energy is the key to India’s energy security and this means a basket of energy sources. 

Now let me come to nuclear energy : India’s current weak economic position and huge energy requirement makes us choose fission over fusion in the short run. This is why the government aims to setup 10 more nuclear power plants(fission tech). It’s also true that H.J.Bhaba’s idea of 3 stage nuclear programme is a brilliant actionable idea. India is already invested in the same. It’s called brilliant because it takes care of nuclear waste arising from the first stages and combines thorium(an abundantly available mineral)a fertile material in the third stage. More importantly, the tech is indigenously developed. So that takes care of most of the current problems with nuclear energy. But still we are left with nuclear waste in the third stage and safety issues of these reactors.  

But make no mistake : Fusion tech is the future - simply because it is more environment friendly than fission. 

It’s also not that solar panels require only space. Even if we import 100% ,make space for it on every rooftop(which is huge by the way), give subsidies equal to our food subsidy, develop/import the battery tech, the most  important problem would be the disposal of solar panels which is a bigger environmental problem than nuclear energy waste. 

So, u see my friend, I am not blind to the side effects of solar energy. I think u were mislead by my first comment. 

In my first comment, I was indirectly referring to the government’s programmes for 2022 - 75th year of Indian independence and India’s third INDC  to Paris Agreement. Out of the target of 175 GW from NRE, India aims to produce 100 GW from solar energy. Through the comment, I implied that the government was way behind its target for solar energy(actually wind energy have overtaken solar)- the biggest component of India’s total target. I was not pitching for solar energy. Just hinting at the government’s slow pace in the total energy basket.

author: Mind Mapping
text:
The crude reality 
Introduction
* world's biggest crude-processing facility in Ab-qaiq and the kingdom's second-biggest oil field in Khurais attacked 
* Global oil prices surged the most -strike on a Saudi Arabian oil facility removed about 5% of global supplies
* US has blamed on Iran
* Saudi Aramco lost about 5.7 million barrels per day 
*  Iran denies involvement in the air attacks, Iran-aligned Houthi rebels in Yemen claimed the attacks 

Severity of situation
* Global oil disruptions-1979-Iranian revolution, 1990- Kuwait attacks by Saddam Hussain 
* Last four years-Yemen war, Djibouti attacked
* Crucial phase- removal of John Bolton, Israel elections 
* Factors-Iran, Shia , Yemen, Bolton, Pompeii 
* IEA- no grave concern as of now

Impact over India 
* India Imports more than 80% crude, imports-70% from Middle East, SA is no one supplier since many years, Saudi- largest exporter in the world, more than 10 million barrels/day, Saudi leads OPEC, SA supplies 10% 
* OPEC has cut down production 
* India- 10 million Tonnes- strategic reserves, requirement-20 million tonnes/month, total-140 million tonnes, sufficient for 10-12 days 
* Price volatility
* Dependents- Reliance refinery, psu refineries, BP, HP, IOC 

Serious Concerns 
* Qatar conflagration 
* Economy not in great shape- US , Russia been pumping more oil than they had in past 
* Risk premiums on oil fields will be more 
* Strait of Hormuz- more than 29% oil Flows, Iran threatens to close it 
* Indian diaspora in Middle East 

Way Forward
* Saudi-Missile/drone shields for resource & processing protection 
* US-Iran diplomacy 
* India-Medium term strategy & Long term strategy- reduce crude oil dependency, increase renewable energy sources, R& D in coal, nuclear energy 
* India-US diplomacy on Iran sanctions, oil imports from Iran 

Conclusion 
Geopolitics always affects oil supplies and prices. The situation creates uncertainty thus price volatility is here to remain as it’s going to create a psychological  shortage & impact. Saudi has made sure that India’s need will be met. So availability is not much of a concern but the prices might be. India thus needs to plan for R&D in coal and review its renewable energy areas
